1
svasti śrī-vijaya-skandhāvārāT| mātr̥-gaṇa-parirakṣitānāṁ mānavya-sagotrāṇāṁ
hāritī-putrāṇāM Aśvamedha-yājināṁ calukyānāṁ kula-jalanidhi
-samutpatnna-rāja-ratnasya sakala-bhuvanaṁ-maṇḍala-maṇḍita-kīrttieḥ śrī
-kīrttivarmmaṇaḥ pautraḥ Aneka-samara-saṁghaṭṭa-vijayinaḥ para-nara
pati-makuṭa-maṇi-mayūkhāvadāta-caraṇa-yugalasya śrī-viṣṇuvarddhana
-mahārājasya priya-tanayaḥ pravarddhamāna-pratāpopanata-samasta
-sāmanta-maṇḍalaḥ sva-bāhu-bala-parākkramopārjjita-sakala-yaśo
-vibhāsita-digantaraḥ sva-śakti-traya-triśūlāvabhinna-para-narapati
-sakala-bala-cetanaḥ br̥haspatir iva naya-jño manur iva vinaya
-jñaḥ yudhiṣṭhira Iva dharmma-parāyaṇaḥ Arjunavad apara-nara
patibhir anabhilaṁghita-pauruṣyaḥ Aneka-śāstrārttha-tatva-jñaḥ para
ma-brahmaṇyo mātā-pitr̥-pādānudhyātaḥ śrī-prithivī-jayasiṅha-va
2
llabha-mahārājaḥ guddavādi-viṣayie viṣaya-mahattarān adhikāra-pu
ruṣāṁś ca Imam arttham ājñāpayaty asti

viditam astu vo ’yam asmābhiḥ
guddavādi-viṣaye pulobūṁran nāma-grāmaḥ veda-vedāṁga
-vido dāmaśarmmaṇaḥ pautrāya sva-pitur adhika-guṇa-gaṇādhi
vāsasya śivaśarmmaṇaḥ putrāya taittirika-sabrahmacāriṇe veda
-dvayālaṁkr̥ta-śariīrāya gotama-sagotrāya sva-karmmānuṣṭhāna
-parāya pūrvvāgrahārika-rudraśarmmaṇo Asanapura-sthāna-vaāstavyāya
śrī-sarvvasiddhi-datyā sarvva-kara-parihāreṇāgrahārīkr̥tya samprattaḥ

tathā bhavadbhir aṇnyaiś ca dharmmādhiśgata-buddhibhiḥ paripālanīyaḥ|
na kaiścid bādhā karaṇīyā| Ājñaptir atra hastikośao vīrakośao yo
sa-gītāḥ

app.note: There is quite a lot of damage around these characters, though the characters themselves are all clear. There is also a rather wide space between bhā and si, filled with damage. Possibly something else was engraved here, then struck out and overwritten.

Rangacharya notes that the visarga is cut twice. There is also quite extensive damage behind these otherwise clear characters; possibly, a previous reading (also ending in a visarga) was struck out and the current one engraved over it.

According to Rangacharya's editor, what Rangacharya saw as an i is only a crack in the plate, and the e is clearly present as the expected vowel marker. While the latter is correct, the crack seems to be there in addition to a fully formed i mātrā, so I assume the engraving was corrected.
The improved reading is by Rangacharya's editor; I mark up unclear and supplied as visible in the scanned estampage.

I am hesitant to alter a reading that has made its way into the name of this grant, yet I am quite certain that Rangacharya's reading is incorrect, and the character we have here is a cursive lo. In glyphs for lī that I could find, if the vowel mark is a spiral open on the top, then the tail is on the left side. Compare the identical-looking lo in lokāśrayā°, line 18 of the Peddavegi plates, and the different (though unclear) lī in vimalīkr̥ta, line 17 of the Niḍupaṟu Grant. Rangacharya also gives the plausible-looking reconstruction pulibūru, which would indicate that pulībūṁra is to be preferred; however, his tentative identification with modern Polamūru does not rule out pulobūṁra. The reading reported in ARIE is pulebūṁra with the e marked as uncertain, and reading le does not seem possible.
As Rangacharya notes, there is a dot before the first character, at the position of a headmark.

According to Rangacharya, the letter vyā is indistinct, the lower part alone being clear. It is further beneath the punctuation mark and not separate. I see no punctuation mark, nor does Rangacharya print one in his edition. There is also no subscript y, only a clear yo. Further, both instances of ś have conspicuous horns, which do not occur in any śa in these plates, all of which have plain, rounded tops. These may be o mātrās shortened to conserve space (being different from the śo of yaśo in l7), or they may be ornamentation. Given the obscurity of these names/terms, I have no way of confidently interpreting the text. Rangacharya may be correct in assuming that yo was intended for vyā, in which case the intended text was probably hastikośo vīrakośaḥ| vyāsa-gītāḥ. Alternatively, yo may be deliberate, in which case vyā was omitted and is to be supplied in line 23. The intended text may thus have been hastikośa-vīrakośayoḥ| vyāsa-gītāḥ. See also the commentary.

My reading is a desperate one, based on the scanned estampage and not pretending to be correct. In the ARIE report, the date is recorded as [1]5th year (in numerical symbols), [śu.] di. 6, [Sunday]. A punctuation mark does not seem likely here, but the two verticals after saṁ resemble nothing else. The next character is probably what the ARIE report read as 5; I would be more inclined to see it as 10, but it resembles neither the 5 nor the 10 in line 20 of the Cīpurupalle plates. This may be followed by another character or even two, squeezed underneath the descender of the first yasya in the previous line. After this comes a character that may be di and was probably read as such in ARIE. I would expect either a month name or, as in the, Cīpurupalle plates, mā here. The next character is probably what was read as 6 in ARIE, followed by what may be vi, which may have prompted the ARIE decipherer to write Sunday. There is possibly one more character with an i, or perhaps a punctuation mark, after this.
